instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: The board works fine but after five minutes the fan speeds very fast and <CHIP>U5850</CHIP> get very hot HELP...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<CHIP>U5850</CHIP> not getting hot works fine..
<TRANSISTOR>Q3200</TRANSISTOR> now gets very hot have changed it no changed and replaced <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> no changes

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: <TRANSISTOR>Q3200</TRANSISTOR> gets hot when you connect charger on different port?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: no just tested it now...only gets very hot when connected to the first port on the left

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Compare diode mode readings around Q/<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> with the other ports.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Is the "first port on the left" corresponding to <TRANSISTOR>Q3200</TRANSISTOR>???
Please, STOP using "cardinal" references; don't you have boardview?

Board still working when charger is connected on that port?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I want to post a picture of how i placed the board but it says file too large

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Board still working when charger is connected on the port where <TRANSISTOR>Q3200</TRANSISTOR> is located

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Does it get very hot?
There shouldn't be a problem, if it works.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: It gets very hot and fan speeds very fast

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Interchange it with <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> from another port.
Then check which chip overheats again.
